Award.AwardTitle: The origin and accumulation of hybrid incompatibilities in Tigriopus californicus
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the mechanisms by which new species arise is a fundamental goal of biology. Diverging populations accumulate genetic differences that may cause conflicts (reduced fitness) when populations come back together and hybridize. This leads to further isolation of the populations, and, eventually, to speciation. Speciation work in model systems has concentrated on conflicts involving the gender-determining chromosomes, but a great number of organisms across the tree of life lack these chromosomes. This project uses a copepod, a small marine invertebrate, to understand how genetic conflicts underlying speciation evolve in organisms without gender-determing chromosomes. By hybridizing pairs of populations from a known evolutionary tree, the study will assess how different types of conflicts (nuclear-nuclear vs. nuclear-mitochondrial) accumulate over time and whether the same chromosomal regions evolve conflicts in evolutionarily independent lineages. It will assess the repeatability of evolutionary trajectories by tracking genetic changes in large, lab-based hybrid populations and will identify potential candidate genes involved in conflicts.

This project relates to issues of biodiversity and conservation by exploring how the lack of sex chromosomes impacts species diversification and consequences of hybridization. Its focus on the evolution of nuclear-mitochondrial conflicts, an important cause of disease, gives this study potential biomedical applications. The project will train a postdoctoral researcher, Ph.D. students, and numerous undergraduate researchers. It will also include outreach to diverse communities in and around Los Angeles, including a collaboration with the Aquarium of the Pacific aimed at promoting awareness of the evolutionary processes currently at work in the ocean and their importance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A fundamental goal of biology is to understand the mechanisms by which new species arise. As populations diverge they accumulate genetic differences that can create conflicts when populations come back together and hybridize. This can lead to further isolation of the populations, ultimately resulting in speciation. Much of the most rigorous work on the nature of these genetic conflicts has focused on Drosophila fruitflies, and many of the conflicts have been found to involve sex chromosomes. This project used a copepod, a small marine invertebrate, to understand how genetic conflicts underlying speciation evolve in organisms without sex chromosomes. Pairs of populations to be hybridized were chosen from a known evolutionary tree to test how conflicts accumulate over time in independent evolutionary lineages. Assays were done in both male and female hybrids to test whether genetic conflicts are sex-specific.

Results for different categories of hybrids (non-recombinant backcrosses and recombinant inbred lines) showed strong asymmetry between reciprocal crosses (female A x male B vs. female B x male A) implicating conflicts between cytoplasmic genes inherited from the mother and nuclear genes inherited from both parents. These asymmetries were greatest in crosses between the most divergent populations, in contrast to theoretical predictions that asymmetries should level out over evolutionary time. Male hybrids had consistently lower survivorship than female hybrids, and also showed up to 10x more genetic markers associated with reduced hybrid viability. This is striking because work on Drosophila has led to the common belief that viability genes are largely shared between the sexes. In two crosses, male-specific incompatibilities mapped to several transposable elements (sequences of DNA that move from one location in the genome to another). While such elements have been previously implicated in reproductive isolation, this would be the first evidence of their role in sex-specific incompatibilities.

Beyond the specific scientific goals, this project had numerous broader impacts. The work supported the research of one postdoc, one Ph.D. student, two laboratory research technicians and eleven undergraduates. The project also supported a collaboration with the Aquarium of the Pacific in Long Beach, including a series of workshops and "Evolution Days" at the aquarium, aimed at promoting understanding of the real-world importance of evolution. Finally, the project included continued outreach to K-12 students in diverse communities in the Los Angeles area, with particular emphasis on promoting careers in STEM.
